title: Interview: Frank Turner
content:
‘I bought my soul back from the Devil/And now I’m keeping it all to myself‘, and so begins Frank Turner‘s most recent, and critically acclaimed, album ‘Poetry of The Deed‘.

Created in his post-hardcore origins, Frank Turner‘s acoustic sound rages with the burning desire to cast aside the oppressing evils of the world, and to pursue an anarchic passion to enjoy life while we can. Currently touring around Australia, New Zealand and China, Frank Turner kindly found time to answer a few of our questions.

CITR: If you had to cite one band/artist as a major influence upon you, who would it be?

Probably Bruce Springsteen. He’s such an incredible singer, songwriter, lyricist and performer. I always go back to his work and find new inspirations.

CITR: What has been your favourite gigging experience to date?

There are too many to choose from. The last UK headline tour was very special, playing venues of that size (like the Roundhouse), but then I played a sold out bar show in Vancouver the other day that was awesome as well.

CITR: What inspired you to move from the post-hardcore nature of ‘Million
Dead’ to the your now more acoustic grounding?

Many things. Partly just a changing taste in music as I got older, partly feeling pretty bored with hardcore, partly the stress of the band breaking up. I tried it out and felt like I’d found my place in life,
which was a good feeling. Still is.

CITR: Two of your songs, ‘The Journey of the Magi’ and ‘I knew Prufrock Before

He Got Famous’ appear to allude to poems written by T. S. Eliot.
Arguably both of the poems alluded to demonstrate feelings of defeat and
mundanity, whereas your respective songs appear to promote a more
positive and proactive approach to life. How important is this contrast
to you not only in these songs, but in all of your work?

I’m a big fan of Eliot, and many other modernist poets as well (Auden, Larkin etc.). I guess it’s probably fair to say that I have a slightly more optimistic bent than Eliot, haha, I hadn’t thought about it like
that before. But I suppose you could say that one of my overarching themes is laughing in the face of adversity (or reality, depending on how you want to look at it). Life is nasty, brutish and short, so we might as well have fun with it.

CITR: You established yourself as a well known artist after years of extensive
touring, with word of mouth playing a great part in people’s recognition
of your music. With many current artists trying to reach out to their
audience through online mediums such as myspace, how important would you
say touring is to the development of yourself as an artist and your music?

It’s been very important for me, I’m pretty old fashioned in that sense.
I think it can be important for bands, but it doesn’t have to be, the
internet is a very powerful medium. I don’t like to try and draw general
rules on music industry progress from my own experience, I’m not sure
I’m a paradigm. Ha.

CITR: When can we expect to a new album to be released? In what ways will it
be a development from ‘Poetry of the Deed’?

I’m working on a lot of new material right now, but I’m also not in as
much of a hurry as I have been in recent years – I’m quite into the idea
of letting these songs percolate for a while longer, so far I’ve been
working on the “release and be damned” approach, I think it’d be fun to
let things settle a little more. Directionally-speaking, who knows. I’m
deeply into Nick Cave, Gomez and The Band at the moment. Go figure.

CITR: PC or Mac?

Mac please. I like computers that work!

CITR: What was the funniest thing you did/witnessed at University?

Hm, it was quite a while ago now, and I spent most of that time running
around with Million Dead anyways. Pass.
